lines.text: You know, I'll never forget my old dad. When these things would happen to him... the things he'd say to me.
"What the hell are you doing in the bathroom day and night? Why don't you get out of there and give someone else a chance?"
Why are you talking that way?
But they told me it was "ee-gor."
Well, they were wrong then, weren't they?
[Froederick and Igor are exhuming a dead criminal]

[to Igor]
Now that brain that you gave me. Was it Hans Delbruck's?
Ah! Very good. Would you mind telling me whose brain I DID put in?
I'm almost sure that was the name.

[chuckles, then]
Are you saying that I put an abnormal brain into a seven and a half foot long, fifty-four inch wide GORILLA?
Is that what you're telling me?

[Reading from his grandfathers' notebook]
"As the minuteness of the parts formed a great hinderance to my speed, I resolved therefore to make a being of a gigantic stature."
Of course. That would simplify everything.
his veins, his feet, his hands, his organs vould all have to be increased in size.
He vould have an enormous schwanzstucker.
He's going to be very popular.
[Frederick, Inga and Igor find an abandoned violin]

Love is the only thing that can save this poor creature, and I am going to convince him that he is loved even at the cost of my own life. No matter what you hear in there, no matter how cruelly I beg you, no matter how terribly I may scream, do not open this door or you will undo everything I have worked for. Do you understand? Do not open this door.
[Dr. Frederick Frankenstein goes into the room with The Monster. The Monster wakes up]

Let me out. Let me out of here. Get me the hell out of here. What's the matter with you people? I was joking! Don't you know a joke when you hear one? HA-HA-HA-HA. Jesus Christ, get me out of here! Open this goddamn door or I'll kick your rotten heads in! Mommy!
Oh, do you like it? I'm not partial to desserts myself, but this is excellent.
To you. You just made a yummy sound, so I thought you liked the dessert.
I didn't make a yummy sound, I just asked you what it is.
But you did. I just heard it.
Well, now look here. If it wasn't you, and it wasn't you...
Hallo. Vould you like to have a roll in ze hay?
[She begins to roll in the hay]
Roll, roll, roll in ze hay.

[to Inga from behind the bookcase]
Put... the candle... back!
Oh. Where you going?... Oh, you men are all alike. Seven or eight quick ones and then you're out with the boys to boast and brag. YOU BETTER KEEP YOUR MOUTH SHUT. Oh... I think I love him.
You know, I'm a rather brilliant surgeon. Perhaps I can help you with that hump.
[after failing to bring the creature to life]
No. No. Be of good cheer. If science teaches us anything, it teaches us to accept our failures, as well as our successes, with quiet dignity and grace.
Son of a bitch! Bastard! I'll get you for this! What did you do to me? What did you do to me.
Stop it! Stop that! Stop it! You'll kill him!
I don't want to live. I do not want to live.

[to The Monster]
Hello handsome. You're a good looking fellow, do you know that? People laugh at you, people hate you, but why do they hate you? Because... they are jealous. Look at that boyish face. Look at that sweet smile. Do you wanna talk about physical strength? Do you want to talk about sheer muscle? Do you want to talk about the Olympian ideal? You are a God. And listen to me, you are not evil. You... are... good.
[the Monster starts to cry, and Dr. Frederick Frankenstein hugs him]

This is a nice boy. This is a good boy. This is a mother's angel. And I want the world to know once and for all, and without any shame, that we love him. I'm going to teach you. I'm going to show you how to walk, how to speak, how to move, how to think. Together, you and I are going to make the greatest single contribution to science since the creation of fire.

[from outside]
Dr. Fronkensteen! Are you all right!
Are you sure this is how they did it?
Yes! It's all written down in the notes! Now tie off the kites and hurry down as fast as you can!
There's a possibility of electrocution! Do you understand?
I said, there is a possibility of electrocution! Do you understand?

[suddenly appears next to Fredrick]
I understand. I understand. Why are you shouting?
Igor, help me with the bags.

[Imitating Groucho Marx]
Soitenly. You take the blonde, I'll take the one in the toiben.
I was talking about the luggage.
Vee had better confeerm de fect dat Yunk Frankenshtein iss indeed VALLOWING EEN EES GANDFADDA'S VOOTSHTAPS.
Oh. Ze platform. Oh, zat, yah, yah... yes.

For as long as I can remember people have hated me. They looked at my face and my body and they ran away in horror. In my loneliness I decided that if I could not inspire love, which is my deepest hope, I would instead cause fear. I live because this poor half-crazed genius, has given me life. He alone held an image of me as something beautiful and then, when it would have been easy enough to stay out of danger, he used his own body as a guinea pig to give me a calmer brain and a somewhat more sophisticated way of expressing myself.

[to The Monster]
Honey, did you see I put another hamper in the bathroom? This one's for your shirts, the other's just for socks and poo-poo undies.
Isn't it true that Darwin preserved a piece of vermicelli in a glass case until, by some extrordinary means, it actually began to move with voluntary motion?
Are you speaking of the worm or the spaghetti?
Yes, I did read something of that incident when I was a student, but you have to remember that a worm... with very few exceptions... is not a human being.
But wasn't that the whole basis of your grandfather's work? The reanimation of dead tissue?
My grandfather was a very sick man.
But as a Fronkensteen, aren't you the least bit curious about it? Doesn't the bringing back to life what was once dead hold any intrigue to you?
You are talking about the nonsensical ravings of a lunatic mind! Dead is dead!
But look at what has been done with hearts and kidneys...
Hearts and kidneys are tinker toys! I am talking about the central nervous system!
Wait Master, it might be dangerous... you go first.

From that fateful day when stinking bits of slime first crawled from the sea and shouted to the cold stars, "I am man.", our greatest dread has always been the knowledge of our mortality. But tonight, we shall hurl the gauntlet of science into the frightful face of death itself. Tonight, we shall ascend into the heavens. We shall mock the earthquake. We shall command the thunders, and penetrate into the very womb of impervious nature herself.
Yes. It's in your blood - it's in the blood of ALL Frankensteins. It reaches the soul when words are useless. Your grandfather used to play it to the creature HE vas making.
Then it was you all the time.
You played that music in the middle of the night...
That was YOUR cigar smoldering in the ashtray.
And it was you... who left my grandfather's book out for me to find.
YES. YES. Say it. He vas my... BOYFRIEND.
[Frankenstein, Igor and Inga in front of HUGE castle doors]
I came to tell you that your fiance should be arriving any second!
I suggest you put on a tie!
Wait. Where are you going? I was going to make Espresso.
You haven't even touched your food.
[Frederick explodes and slaps on his food]
There. Now I've touched it. Happy?
[as she holds a candle holder with 3 unlit candles]
Stay close to the candles. The stairway can be... treacherous.
[following Igor's botched attempt to interpret Dr. Frankenstein's charade clues while being attacked by the monster]
STAND BACK, FOR THE LOVE OF GOD! HE'S GOT A ROTTEN BRAIN!
It's not rotten! It's a good brain!
IT'S ROTTEN, I TELL YOU! ROTTEN!

[singing, while having sex with the monster]
Oh, sweet mystery of life at last I've found you! At last, I know the secret of it all!
You know, there's something I've been meaning to ask you. In the transference, the monster got part of your wonderful brain. But what did you ever get from him?

[gasping]
Oh my goodness, I don't believe...
[emits several somewhat painful-sounding moans and grunts]

[singing]
Oh, sweet mystery of life, at last I've found you!

[Peek back out from the castle's door]
Blucher!

[dreaming]
I am not a Frankenstein. I'm a Fronkensteen. Don't give me that. I don't believe in fate. And I won't say it.
All right, you win. You win. I give. I'll say it. I'll say it. I'll say it. DESTINY! DESTINY! NO ESCAPING THAT FOR ME! DESTINY! DESTINY! NO ESCAPING THAT FOR ME!
For what we are about to see next, we must enter quietly into the realm of genius.
Dirty word! He said a dirty word!
I am a scientist, not a philosopher! You have more chance of reanimating this scalpel than you have of mending a broken nervous system!
But what about your grandfather's work, sir?
My grandfather's work was doodoo! I am not interested in death! The only thing that concerns me is the preservation of life!
[jams the scalpel into his leg, lets go of the scalpel and it sticks upright out of his leg, grasps it again, then slowly crosses his legs to block the scalpel from view]
Two nasty lookin' switches over there, but I'm not going to be the first.
[Frau Blucher has just "walked in" on Frederick and Inga in the lab]
I thought I told you never to interrupt me while I'm working!
With such a specimen for a body, all we need now is an equally magnificant brain. You know what to do?
I have a pretty good idea.

[pointing to Igor's hump]
Good man. Didn't you, didn't you use to have that on the other side?
Would the doctor care for a... brandy before retiring?
No... thank you very much. No thanks.
NOTHING! Thank you! I'm a little - tired!
Then I vill say... goodnight, Herr Doctor.
My grandfather used to work for your grandfather. Of course the rates have gone up.

...tists - and neurosurgeons, ladies and gentlemen. A few short weeks ago, coming from a background, believe me, as conservative and traditionally grounded in scientific fact as any of you, I began an experiment in, incredulous as it may sound, the reanimation of dead tissue.
Have all the preperations been made for the transference?
Are you sure you want to go through with this?
It's the only thing that can save him now.
You realize you're risking both your lives?
Let's all go have some sponge cake and a little wine...
[the Monster shakes his mechanical hand, popping it off]
Pardon me, boy. Is this the Transylvania station?
Ja, ja. Track 29. Can I give you a shine?
Well it seems as if our mysterious violinist has disa...

[after reading his grandfather's notes]
IT... COULD... WORK!
[Dr. Frankenstein leans in for a kiss]

[pulling away]
No, the dress is taffeta. It wrinkles so easily.
Gone! Gone! We've got to find him, you understand? We've got to find him before he kills someone! What have I done? Oh God in Heaven! What have I done?
Please! Remain in your seats, I beg you! We are not children here, we are scientists! I assure you there is nothing to fear!
Hold on to your hat! I'll be right back.

[literally holds onto his hat]
I'm holding onto it, Darling!
A riot is an ungly thing... undt, I tink, that it is chust about time ve had vun.

[singing]
If you're blue, and you don't know where to go to, why don't you go where fashion sits...
I heard the strangest music from the upstairs kitchen and I just... followed it down. Call it... a hunch. Ba-dum chi.
To wash up. I've got to look normal.
We've all of us got to behave normally.
It's gonna be a long night. If you need any help with the girls, I'll be...
[picks last petal off a flower and throws it into the well]
Now throw a kiss and say "Bye bye."
Oh dear. Nothing left. What shall we throw in now?

[During game of darts, the Inspector has made it appear that he has thrown all bullseyes, while Dr. Frankenstein's back was turned]
Nice grouping!

[turns in Igor's direction to speak, changes her mind, then looks back to Inga]
How do you do?
Uh, this is my financier, Elizabeth.
Oh, I'm so happy to meet you at last!
Excuse me darling, what is exactly that you do do?

[sings]
I ain't got no body, and nobody cares for me. Yakka tak ta a yakka tak ta ha!
[after he brings the creature to life]

[holds up his wooden arm]
To the lumber yard!
Please, I beg you! For safety's sake, don't humiliate him!
LIFE! DO YOU HEAR ME? GIVE MY CREATION... LIFE!
My grandfather... was a very... SICK... man.
